[bq="Randomosaur"]"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/536c4afc63687229657d0100#post_536c4afc63687229657d0100
118? Citation needed.[/bq]
I'm trying really hard to think of where I read this.  You know those times where you read a newspaper and remember the information, but you forget what newspaper you were reading?  I'm having one of those moments right now.  I remember they were talking about how researchers for years have thought that there might be others and that theoretically we could potentially create more.  Argh, I'm trying really hard to remember which science news was I reading again.  I'll get back to you when I remember. *edit  Crap, I just can not for the life of me seem to remember where I read this from.

topics.body:
"@twistedmetalero":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/536cdb4b63687258be3c0000#post_536cdb4b63687258be3c0000
The Build I mention above is not considered high end, it's more like ultra end. Something like that would be able to do pretty much anything you could ever ask it to. You've got 16 cores/32 threads to play with and more RAM than most hard drives. Each FirePro GPU costs as much as a decent used car. Were this the early 2000's this single build could be it's own movie studio; I could make _Toy Story_ in a few days at the most, where it took months to make it back in the late 90's.

This isn't even what I would call high end. Try _8_ CPU's with 15 cores/30 threads each (the Xeon 8895v2) and a juicy 1.5TB of RAM; actually I would hold out for the new Xeon's which are supposed to have 18 cores/36 threads _each_. Could it run Crysis? Yes, 30 instances at once in fact if we give each one 4 cores, all of them at the highest quality level possible. This of course is provided that somehow each instance could have it's own dedicated GPU.

topics.body: After waking up this morning, "Well time to see what's new in the world" (reads the news) (all about monica lewinsky) . . . . Seriously? . . Seriously?  Has the news taken such a nosedive in quality that we're now repackaging seventeen year old events and calling it "news"?  Next thing we know we're going to "news" stories about the signing of the declaration of independence calling it the next big thing or something.

topics.body:
"@SquiggyBomb":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/536cee2563687252222f0300#post_536cee2563687252222f0300
Cause hillary is probably going to run for president and the news at this point has reached the point of, "If I can't find a presidential scandal I'll make a presidential scandal".


I have a feeling that if we ever reach the point where global peace has happened, crime rates are next to nil, poverty is a thing of the past and so forth we'll just see in the news retreads of old stories to keep viewership up.  I can imagine it now, "Tonight on 24/7 news!  Can disease make a comeback after nanomachines have given us borderline biological immortality?  Sure all the doctors say that could never happen as thanks to nanomachines getting rid of any new disease is just a new software update patch, *BUT* what do people in their professional field know?  It's not like they can predict spread of disease or anything.  CDC?  More like Cd-lame; check out our new tweets at #totallynotbullshit"
topics.author: 38b55cdf63616403d7560600
